User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:2.0b12pre) Gecko/20110205 Firefox/4.0b12pre
Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:2.0b12pre) Gecko/20110205 Firefox/4.0b12pre

See Bug 606909 Comment 23

Putting the indicator arrow beneath the tab seems like a bad idea to me. Unless
the tab preview is transparent (it's not for me), the arrow will be obscured
50% of the time.

Plus, bottom-up indicators in a top-down UI feel both out-of-place and awkward.

Suggestion:
Revert changes made in Bug 606909. Instead, change the top margin to be 0px, so that the tab indicator is drawn within the tab bar at the top of the tab.

End result:
Tab drop indicators are no longer obscured by the title bar, fall off-window, or are covered by tab previews.

Alternate, more flashy/modern suggestion:
Remove the drop indicator arrow altogether. Instead use a colorized gradient/glow on the edges of the tabs indicating the drop area.

Reproducible: Always
comments.creator: sparky@bluefang-logic.com

comments.text:
I agree with this as a significant issue. In FF 3.x, the orange indicator (on Win, standard theme) that displayed between tabs during a drag indicated very clearly where the dragged tab would be dropped. In FF 4, most of the time I can't see the little arrow. In fact, the first time I did a drag in FF 4, I didn't notice that there was one. The mouse pointer can obscure the arrow. Additionally, the background color of the rendered page can make the arrow nearly invisible.

I'm not sure why the change was made from 3.x to 4, but I'd be thrilled to simply return to the 3.x behavior.
